LSU and Louisiana 's other public universities have had a difficult time hiring more faculty because of the dramatic cuts to higher education elected officials have imposed over the last few years .
A recent report from the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities found the state had reduced its higher education budget more than almost any other state in the country over the last six years .

So Alexander was raising the alarm over the petroleum engineering program , primarily as a way to advocate for more higher education money at a Louisiana Senate Finance Committee meeting Monday ( May 19 ) .
He wants the Louisiana Legislature to include some targeted funding for high - demand job fields , like petroleum engineering , in the budget for state universities and colleges next year .
The extra money would allow LSU to hire as many as four more faculty members for the petroleum engineering program , he said .
